page.title: 02Auchtermuchty's History
page.content: Auchtermuchty is a small town with a large history.Auchtermuchty means{ {uplands of the wild boar.}The town has been built near the site of a{Roman {camp.}In the{15th century}the area was thickly covered with forest.{Mary {Queen of Scots}and other members of the{Royal Family}hunted wild boar. In{1517}the town was created a{Royal {Burgh}and in{1595 King James VI}gave it a new{Charter}and included 3,000 acres of land. Between{1800 and 1900}the population was doubled due to the great increase in{handloom weaving.}The Burgh was at its most prosperous about 1815. In{ {1817}all the local linen merchants became bankrupt. The burgh, with debts of almost Â£3,000 was forced to sell the Burgh lands and two mills. Auchtermuchty is now administered by {North East Fife District Council.
